title: Mystery as sea at UK beaches turns orange and leaves swimmers with rash

The sea has turned orange along several points of England's south coast, with some swimmers reportedly coming out of the water in a rash.

The Environment Agency and South West Water are investigating the phenomenon, which has happened at a number of coastal villages in Cornwall

One beach-goer warned others to stay away from the 'contaminated' water, Cornwall Live reports.

Posting on a community Facebook page, one swimmer said: "Caution do not go to Porthpean for the time being as there is a contaminant within the water.

(Image: Ian Harris/Cornwall Live)

(Image: Ian Harris/Cornwall Live)

“Some of us have have been for a swim and coming out in rash.”

The Environment Agency said it is taking samples from the water.

In a tweet posted this evening, a spokesperson said: "We are aware of reports of pink/orange sea colour at #Porthpean , #Duporth and #Charlestown beaches in #Cornwall . We are investigating and will be taking samples."

(Image: Ian Harris/Cornwall Live)

South West Water has also taken to Twitter to assure residents that it is looking into the matter.

Surfers Against Sewage has issued a pollution warning for Portmellon. It is not clear whether this is linked to the change in sea colour.

The alert states: "Bathing not advised today due to the likelihood of reduced water quality.

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

(Image: Surfers Against Sewage)

"Completely covered at high tide, Port Mellon is around 150m long and is a sandy beach with rock pools at low tide.

"It is backed by hills. There is a sewer overflow from Portmellon pumping station that discharges into Portmellon Stream 70m upstream of the beach. This location is covered by Pollution Risk Forecasting."

The water has turned a rusty brown colour at beaches along the south coast of Cornwall, including Porthpean, Duporth and Charlestown.
description: Swimmers were shocked to discover a bright orange 'contaminant' in the water off the coast of Cornwall
